content.webTitle: NRL: what to look out for this weekend

fields.headline: NRL: what to look out for this weekend
fields.bodyText: Baby cats and thunder bunnies And so to mighty ANZ Stadium Friday night for the clash of hot baby Tigers and thunder-thighed Rabbits, a sentence you won’t read outside a very bad porno and ever again in these pages, one would warrant. Last week on the Gold Coast, sweating it out in temperatures described as “44 degrees” by local colour men, the Tigers slaughtered the dumbfounded Titans, their colts James Tedesco and Luke Brooks having more fun than happy pants. The pair won’t be afforded the same leeway this week against the Angry Burgess Brothers and the rest of the hard-faced Rabbits, indeed they will have their tender bits and faces rubbed, and quite roughly. Which should be good. Both sides sport thundering props, good halves, class hookers, and piss-fast wing men. But the Bunnies have Greg Inglis. And he dominates State of Origin much less a bunch of big baby cats. Saturday night special And so to a Saturday night special, a dinkum Derby at Remondis Stadium née Shark Park, between St George-Illawarra Dragons and Cronulla-Sutherland Sharks. The former were plenty of pundits’ spoon nominees yet remain undefeated after two rounds, such is the impossibility of tipping winners in this kooky National Rugby League. The Sharks were (pending the machinations of the drugs in sport imbroglio that’s been around longer than the Devil’s Marbles) a Top-8 moral but without their best players – Paul Gallen and Luke Lewis, to name but two – the Dragons will roast these Sharks in their own park, take it to the bank via Centrebet*. *Do not do this. Beefcake wizards Sunday afternoon at Brookvale Oval sees the ageless (well, since 1967) clash of Sydney’s east (well, north) and west (actually, the geographic centre) as Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles entertain Parramatta Eels. Should be entertaining, especially if you’re a Manly fan because you’ll be able stand in the sun on Brookie Hill, drink a cold tinnie of the local brew “New”, and yell rude things at an Eels side so bad they should be illegal. Perhaps not illegal. But they’re still quite bad, Parra, and if Manly don’t score 40 against them on a fine Sunday arvo at home they’ll be searching for their very souls come training at Narrabeen Monday. Maybe not searching for their souls. In fact they’ll probably be happy enough with the two points and tell their public they’re “looking ahead”, “hopefully”, “moving on”, and “yeah, definitely”, in the way of the modern player, they say nothing these people, they are beefcakes hard-wired by political wizards. Blinking drones of evil Crowds are down in Penrith, they say, apparently half their members – season-ticket holders – don’t actually exercise their rights and attend games. And it’s something that confounds the local powers-that-be. Is it the weather? Is it because the team aren’t travelling that flash? What is it about the “game day experience” that isn’t pumping the nads of the local populace? How about this: much of the funding of Penrith Panthers Rugby League Club comes from Panthers World of Entertainment, the mighty gambling palace adjacent to the football ground. The club has 1,000 poker machines into which members of the local community pour something like $91m in any given year. The club returns a tiny percentage of this income back to “the community” by subsidising footy socks for local kids, and such forth. It’s about 3%. But if the local community wasn’t tipping the money into the poker machines in the first place, would they not have the money in their pocket? Would they then be able to attend games of local rugby league because a) they have the money and b) they’re not playing the bloody pokies? Simplistic, sure. But pokies suck people in like hypnotised moths. And if the footy club could get half the people who pump money into the machines to attend games instead, they’d fill their stadium every week. Plenty of Panthers’ PR is about engaging the community. But these blinking drone machines suck the community dry. Clubs Australia has slick advertising assuring us that “clubs are part of the solution” to problem gambling. That’s like saying “guns don’t kill people, people kill people”. Well, the gun – and the club – has a fair bit to do with it. Australians spend $12bn (billion!) a year on poker machines. You want to know why people aren’t coming to the footy, Panthers? They’re playing pokies in Panthers. Hot Milf And so to Canberra on a Sunday evening and a few reasons to tune in, but one that’ll make you toss away the remote: the little man playing full-back, Anthony Milford. For if Wests Tigers fullback James Tedesco can make Gold Coast Titans look like lumbering, grasping, drunken farm oafs, then little Milfy will have them on their knees and howling at the moon in agony and angst. Watch him run! there hasn’t been a set of flying feet like Milford’s since bouncing baby-faced Innisfail Kid, Kerry Boustead. Last week Milford shredded Newcastle like a … shredder, one of those paper shredders. This week he’ll so frighten the Titans they’ll watch Evil Dead on the bus home to feel better.
